summary: Sometimes I feel like I put myself down.  Like I’m not good enough because I don’t conform and workout like people in a gym....
caption:
Sometimes I feel like I put myself down. Like I’m not good enough because I don’t conform and workout like people in a gym. That my workout is silly or not effective.

I feel like because I don’t get my heart rate to where someone else does. Or don’t break a big time sweat 💦 in every workout 🏋🏻‍♀️ I am not getting it done like others.

We all have to stop comparing ourselves to others
Our abilities are totally different
Our skillset is totally different
Our journeys are totally different
Our WHY for doing what we are is totally different (for me it’s health, sometimes it’s to help with stress, sometimes it’s because I want to feel good on clothes, sometimes it’s because I need flexibility)

Take the voices out of your head that say I can’t, I don’t want to, I’m not good enough and find the one that Motivates your day and life.

One small thing you do can change your whole day!

We all start somewhere and it isn’t a 1 time thing. It’s something we need to do forever to stay healthy.
#health #coachbev #healthylifestyle #weightloss #weightlossjourney #transformationtuesday #fattofit #videooftheday #over45 #fitfam #fitspo
https://www.instagram.com/p/BxcgTaFHgOn/?igshid=1ny2ym2012zsl

summary: Ways To Prevent Migraine Attack
title: Ways To Prevent Migraine Attack
body:
Hacks That Make Life Easier For People Prone To Migraine Attacks

It’s like a thousand, red-hot knives slicing through the head. Every inch hurts. Blinking hurts. Looking down hurts. Turning your head hurts. Showering hurts. Everything hurts when you have a migraine.

There are tablets available to counter the debilitating pain, yet migraines aren’t entirely curable. Majority of the available drugs have strong side effects and they can be quite risky for some people. So, what’s the buzzword for migraine attacks?

Prevention.

Major symptoms of migraine are nausea, dizziness, vomiting, and extreme sensitivity to light and sound. Prevention can start with identifying what triggers these symptoms and then avoiding them.

Avoid Loud Noises & Light: Harsh sunlight, flashes of bright lights at night, music concerts, certain sounds at a higher decibel etc. should be avoided. Taking short breaks while working on computer or watching TV can decrease eye strain.

Watch What You Eat: Certain food items like chocolates, processed meat, red wine etc. can trigger headaches. It has mainly to do with how they affect a person’s digestion, which then manifests as a migraine.

Eat & Sleep on Schedule: Improper sleep and a skewed diet can result in migraines. Dehydration too is a common cause of headaches, especially in summer, so make sure to refill your body with fluids through the day.

Avoid Stress: Yeah, we know, easier said than done in this hectic world. While stressful situations can seem to be beyond our control, we can prepare ourselves on how to react to such situations. Relaxation techniques like meditation and yoga can also help.

Take Supplements: Some people might have an imbalanced natural supplement intake. It is advisable to consult a physician and take necessary supplements to up the nutrient levels.

It takes a little time, but learning what your triggers are and avoiding them can restrict migraines to a great extent. You would still have days of paralysing pain in spite of being careful, so at times like that you can try out some life hacks that people over the world have discovered through time. Mind you, it might or might not work, but rest assured you won’t have any serious side effects.

  • Soaking your feet in hot water right when you feel a little slice of pain can help. Put a cold compress to the forehead and spend the night in a dark room to avoid any stress or strain to the head.

  • Gel ice pack around the head can help. Couple it with muscle relaxing exercise for the face.

  • Make a habit of drinking a bottle of water, or half a bottle at least, as soon as you wake up in the morning.

  • Massages with essential oils, eucalyptus oil etc. around the temples, behind the ear, the neck etc. can help alleviate some of the pain.

  • Avoid glare anywhere; be it sunlight glare of the windows, or headlight glare from vehicles.

Catch your migraine early and sidestep its severity with these hacks.

blog.name: culturecountsresearch
blog.description: Culture Counts is the collective voice of Scotland's cultural sector. https://culturecounts.scot/

summary: How do artistic creative activities regulate our emotions? Validation of the Emotion Regulation Strategies for Artistic Creative...
title: How do artistic creative activities regulate our emotions? Validation of the Emotion Regulation Strategies for Artistic Creative Activities Scale (ERS-ACA) (May 19)
description:
In the largest study of its kind, with almost 50,000 people taking part, last year’s Great British Creativity Test - in partnership with UCL - explored for the first time how creative activities can help us manage our mood and boost wellbeing.  

There is a rich literature exploring emotional responses to engaging in artistic creative activities such as making music, writing, dancing and crafts. However, it remains unclear how such activities affect our emotions; specifically which mental processes (‘strategies’) are used to regulate our emotional responses.

reblog.comment:

blog.name: culturecountsresearch

summary: Changing Lives: the social impact of participation in culture and sport - DCMS (May 19)
title: Changing Lives: the social impact of participation in culture and sport - DCMS (May 19)
description: “Cultural and sporting opportunities have intrinsic value, and can inspire personal success, but to view them only this narrowly would be to fail to understand their true value. Organisations working in these fields are doing so much more. Our inquiry showcases some of the evidence that we received, demonstrating the impact of culture and sport on positive outcomes in health, education, criminal justice and urban regeneration. “

summary: Endometrial Hyperplasia: Causes, Symptoms, Diagnosis And Treatment
title: Endometrial Hyperplasia: Causes, Symptoms, Diagnosis And Treatment
body:
Abnormal uterine bleeding is not uncommon and it is quite likely that you might have approached your doctor at some point of time complaining about such abnormal bleeding. Heavier than normal menstrual bleeding, post-menopausal bleeding or bleeding in between your periods could all be signs of endometrial hyperplasia .

Abnormality of the lining of the uterus or endometrium indicates a condition known as endometrial hyperplasia . Although this condition does not hint at the arrival of cancer, it might lead to uterine cancer in some women, especially if left untreated.

Read on to know more about endometrial hyperplasia and how it can be treated.

What Is Endometrial Hyperplasia?

It is a condition wherein the endometrium (lining of the uterus) turns abnormally thick. This condition occurs when there is an excess of estrogen, but no progesterone .

Your endometrium is what builds up and sheds each month in the form of your regular monthly periods. When there is an imbalance in the hormonal stimulation of the endometrium, an abnormality arises. In women with endometrial hyperplasia, progesterone is not made and the lining of the uterus does not shed itself as a result of missed ovulation . The endometrium continues to grow in response to the rise in production of estrogen. When the cells of the endometrium get crowded abnormally (causing hyperplasia), it may lead to uterine cancer .

The following are some of the conditions that can cause excess production of estrogen, in turn, leading to endometrial hyperplasia:

  • Anovulation: In case you do not ovulate (there can be a variety of reasons), there won’t be an increase in the production of progesterone. If this happens, you will not get your periods, in other words, the lining of your uterus will not shed .
  • Obesity: Presence of fat tissues can make other hormones convert to estrogen . This result in extra estrogen that stimulates the lining of the uterus in addition to the normal estrogen that is produced by the ovaries.
  • Exogenous hormones: Hormonal medication can cause abnormal thickening of the endometrium . For people using hormone replacement therapy, this condition is quite common.
  • Estrogen producing ovarian tumours: Benign ovarian tumours can produce excess estrogen .

Symptoms Of Endometrial Hyperplasia

The major symptoms of this condition are abnormal menstrual bleeding. You should consult your doctor immediately whenever you face any of the following :

  • Menstrual cycles shorter than 21 days
  • Menstrual bleeding between menstrual period cycles
  • Menstrual bleeding that is heavier and lasts longer than usual
  • Pre-menopause (not having a period at all)
  • Post-menopause uterine bleeding

Causes Of Endometrial Hyperplasia

The two main causes of this condition are as follows:

1. Too much estrogen: This is a hormone that plays an important role in the menstrual cycle. Estrogen makes the cells grow . When an abnormal scenario occurs, there can be a production of too many cells.

2. Not enough progesterone: This is also another important hormone for the normal functioning of the menstrual cycle. Progesterone signals the shedding of the cells . When there is an imbalance, it can produce abnormal cells.

Diagnosis Of Endometrial Hyperplasia

When you approach your doctor with complaints of abnormal uterine bleeding, you are most likely to be advised to undergo a biopsy of the lining of the uterus. Either of the following two procedures could be tried out :

1. Endometrial biopsy: This is a very common gynecologic procedure. However, to minimize the cramping during or after the procedure, you can carry a small warm pack with you. Also, you can choose to have a little snack about an hour before the procedure. The procedure is almost like a routine pap smear. Your cervix is held using a grasper and a small aspirator device is inserted . The discomfort experienced might be like mild period cramps. The procedure will last less than a minute.

2. Hysteroscopy: At times, your doctor might suggest that you get a hysterectomy done instead of an endometrial biopsy. The benefit of this procedure is that the doctor can get a direct view of the lining of the uterus . This procedure ensures that all areas of the endometrium are adequately sampled.

Note that endometrial hyperplasia cannot be diagnosed by a blood test or an ultrasound. However, your doctor might suggest certain blood tests to rule out other causes of abnormal uterine bleeding.

Treatment For Endometrial Hyperplasia

The most common treatment approach is through the use of progestin . This can be taken in the form of a pill, as a shot, vaginal cream or in the form of an intrauterine device.

Complex endometrial hyperplasia increases your risk of getting cancer. In case, one has the atypical type of endometrial hyperplasia (there could be a presence of tumours in the uterus), then she should consider a hysterectomy (a surgical process of getting the uterus removed). This is recommended if you no longer wish to conceive .

For the younger women who wish to have babies in the future, progesterone therapy works best.

Risk Factors And Prevention Of Endometrial Hyperplasia

Women who have gone through menopause are more likely to have this condition. This is because the menstrual cycle changes along with the bodily hormones.

The following are some of the risk factors associated with this condition :

  • Obesity
  • First menstrual cycle at an early age
  • Long-term use of medicines containing high levels of estrogen
  • Use of tobacco
  • Not being pregnant ever
  • Going through menopause at an older age
  • Irregular menstrual cycles
  • Family history of uterine or ovarian cancer.

Although endometrial hyperplasia cannot be prevented, the risks of it occurring can be lowered by

  • taking birth control to regulate hormonal changes,
  • losing weight, if obese and
  • taking medicine with progestin, if you are already taking estrogen medicines.

Also Read:

Hysterectomy: Purpose, Procedure, Risks And Recovery

Is Amenorrhea Treatable? Here Are Interesting Things To Know About This Condition

What Is Implantation Bleeding And How To Recognise It?
